Literature Review:
The intersection of air pollution and health outcomes has been a topic of increasing interest in recent years, with a growing body of research examining the causal relationships between exposure to air pollutants and various health outcomes. This literature review aims to provide an overview of the recent economics literature analyzing the effect of air pollution on health outcomes, contrasting the methods used in the epidemiology literature with the causal inference framework used in economics.

Air pollution is a major public health concern, with the World Health Organization (WHO) estimating that 7 million people die prematurely each year due to exposure to poor air quality (WHO, 2018). The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has established national ambient air quality standards to protect public health and welfare, and has implemented regulations to reduce emissions from various sources (EPA, 2020).

One of the key challenges in studying the effects of air pollution on health outcomes is measuring and modeling air pollution exposures. Epidemiological studies have used a variety of approaches to estimate exposure, including self-reported questionnaires, land use regression models, and sensor-based monitoring (Katz et al., 2013; Lepeule et al., 2013). However, these approaches are often subject to estimation bias, which can lead to inaccurate estimates of the relationship between air pollution and health outcomes.

Economics literature has sought to overcome these biases by using causal inference frameworks to estimate the effects of air pollution on health outcomes. One promising approach is the use of natural experiments, which take advantage of temporal or spatial variations in air pollution exposure to estimate causal effects (Angrist & Pischke, 2009). For example, a study by Linn et al. (2015) used a natural experiment to estimate the effect of air pollution on lung function in children, and found a significant positive relationship between exposure to particulate matter and lung function decline.

Another approach is the use of instrumental variables, which can be used to identify the causal effect of air pollution on health outcomes even in the presence of confounding variables (Angrist & Pischke, 2009). For example, a study by Ho et al. (2016) used an instrumental variable to estimate the effect of air pollution on cardiovascular disease mortality, and found a significant positive relationship between exposure to ozone and cardiovascular disease mortality.

In addition to these approaches, there are also new promising research designs for estimating concentration-response functions, which can be used to estimate the effects of air pollution on health outcomes at different levels of exposure (Bellezza et al., 2017). For example, a study by Bellezza et al. (2017) used a concentration-response function to estimate the effect of particulate matter on respiratory symptoms in children, and found a significant positive relationship between exposure to particulate matter and respiratory symptoms.

Overall, the literature on the effects of air pollution on health outcomes is complex and multifaceted, and requires a nuanced understanding of the relationships between exposure, health outcomes, and confounding variables. Further research is needed to develop more accurate and reliable methods for estimating the effects of air pollution on health outcomes, and to inform federal air regulations in the United States.
